title: Parliamentary Corpora in the CLARIN infrastructure

author: Jakob Lenardič, Faculty of Arts, University of Ljubljana

segmentation: So hello everyone.

My name is Jacqueline, which I'm a PhD student in the research assistant at the Faculty of Arts in Uganda and as a lot of you probably know, I'm helping diarrhea with the user involvement, and as those of you who dropped by our bizarre posters might know, this presentation started as a part of user involvement initiative.
To draft overviews of various language resources and to find out how accessible they are from the perspective of a potential user who might not be that well versed in language technology.
Now.

The records of parliamentary sessions, which are the topic of my presentation, are crucially important resource of language data because of their unique and socially impactful content as well as their idiosyncratic language.
Because of such relevance, parliamentary records can be approached from various research perspectives like political science.
Sociology, history and applicative approaches to linguistics like critical discourse analysis.
Since the Freedom of Information Act in over 100 countries around the world make them freely and widely available.
There have been numerous national as well as international initiatives to compile, process and analyze parliamentary corpora.
The Corrpro are also the subject of a Clarion plus workshop which aimed to bring together corpus developers.

And those researchers who use these resources now one of the crucial aims of this workshop was also to discuss technical issues related to proper structuring and the archiving of such corpora, and to address method methodological questions about how to best use them in different disciplines.
Now this last point, some of the corporate that I'm about to outline in my presentation have already been successfully used by digital humanities researchers.
Although at this point we haven't yet drafted them.
Overview of such use.
One such successful example is related to the finish at parliamentary corpus, where the researcher analyzed the corpus data in relation to the question.

Of when and why nonstandard instances of language are used by the Members of Parliament, a similar example pertains to the analysis of verbal aggressiveness in the Greek Parliament, where the researcher focused on how verbal attacks, especially those related to sexism, are constructed in how corpus linguistics can detect similar examples on the basis of verbal cues that contextualize such aggression.

Now since parliamentary corpora are obviously of great value for various kinds of research, the idea behind our presentation was to gain an understanding of how they are represented in the cloud and infrastructure.

We therefore conducted the survey for all client member countries and also the UK observer and at that point when we conducted the original survey, the Friends Observer didn't yet have its status confirmed.
By means of such a survey, we aimed to identify the existing corpora for these countries, and we mostly focused on user involvement perspective which tried to highlight the Accessibility as well.
Sentation of this corpora and how both of these notions can be optimized.
Now, before we actually tackled the core, part of the corpora, we first surveyed the availability of the records, and it's unsurprisingly.

Turns out that they are freely available for all countries on the relevant websites, except for Estonia, for which we sadly couldn't find the records, and after the presentation I'm glad someone correct me on this point.
Now the records themselves differ from one another in two.
Respect first, the periods that they cover vary widely from country to country.
The oldest records are those from the UK from Norway and from the Netherlands, and in all three cases they date back to the beginning of the 19th century.
On the other hand, the youngest are those of Germany, Poland and the Czech Republic, where this digitized records are basically only a couple of years old.
Now.
The second.
The way in which they differ are the formats and.
They are basically offered in a variety of textual formats in the.
In the majority of cases they format, such as playing ATM, HTML, text, Microsoft Word documents, or XLS.
In four countries, stand out Germany, Italy, Poland and Portugal in the sense that the records.
Available are available only in PDF.
So and this.
Brings me to the actual overview.
And.
Here, here I'd first like to point out that the comprehensive overview is available in a report that is.
It was just yesterday or two days ago.
Uploaded on the new user involvement Web page and you are all welcome to see it.

In All in all, we were able to find 20 corpora that compiled parliamentary dating the languages of declaring member countries, and we also took into account the your Pool Corp, Europe, all parallel corpus of the Proceedings of the European Parliament.
Now, as you can see from the table, our survey focused on trying to find and provide the following information for each.
Corpus first we provide that the name of the corpus and as well as in the.
Original report a hyperlink to the most relevant site, which in some cases is a dedicated dedicated website or a handle link to the repository.

Second, we provided information on the size of the corpus in terms of tokens as well as the period that is covered and 3rd we provided information on basic linguistic imitation, basically tokenization.
Part of speech, tagging and lemmatization.
And finally we detailed how we found the corpus.
In the way and how it is available, available either as a download or through a concordance, Sir.
Now as to this last point, that is availability.

We approached it from a very naive perspective, like from the eyes of humanities researcher who wants to find the parliamentary corpus for a specific learning language, but isn't well versed in the workings of the vlog, for instance.
So basically what we did is we first tried finding a specific corpus through the vlog through basic keyword searches, and if this didn't workout, which, as you later see, see it.

Mostly didn't we turn to the national consortia and the repository risk and we finally contacted the National Coordinators and the National UI representatives who provided us other missing corpora in this overview, those are marked with with email, and we even found one on Google.
Now.
The next slide provides a basic statistics of our findings.
As you can see, we managed to find 1 corpus preclearing country except for Italy, the Czech Republic and Norway.
In the case of Italy, we weren't able to find the corpus and in the case of Norway in the Czech Republic we found two corpora for each.
And generally, and perhaps unsurprisingly, the British corpus is the largest.
OK, the bridge the British corpus is the largest into that consists of 1.6 billion tokens.

Although it must be said that the Swedish corpus their exact is open data isn't far behind with its 1.25 billion tokens since most of the other corpora are much smaller and there are generally generally between 1,000,000 and 100 million tokens in size, I think there are only two others that extend beyond the 100 million limit, and these are the Dutch.
Or the Dutch corpus and the Polish corpus.
Now.
In terms of the time periods that are covered, the corpora vary quite a lot.
However, there are only two corpora which extend back to almost the entire 19th century, and these are the Dutch corpus in the British Hanserd corpus, which is perhaps.
Unsurprising and probably related to the fact that the parliamentary sessions of the Netherlands in Great Britain are also accessible from way back then, as I mentioned.
Now on the next slide you can see that eight of the corpora are available for download.
Seven are available exclusively for online searching through various environments and five are available both for download and online searching.
Here.
I'd like to point out through two things.

As you can see under the first bullet only the Danish Portuguese and Greek corpora are available for download on target through Clarin, repository's and all the other are available on their dedicated websites because, as I'll point out later, they aren't yet integrated or they aren't part of Clarion now.

What's also interested especially for Clarence that's interesting, is that this Swedish and Finnish corpora are available through the Concordance or Corp, which is, you know, is the is the tool of the Swedish Consortium.

And developed their language banks, frog, Duncan, and the Proceedings of the Norwegian Parliamentary debates Corpus, which is one of the two Norwegian ones, is available through the concordance or corpuscular, which is provided by the Norwegian Consortium.
Now the next slide shows the state of the infrastructure.
That is, to what extent a corpus is available through chlorine.
As you can see, only 7 which is less than 1/2 of all the found corpora can be found through the vlo.
These are one of the two Norwegian corpora.
The Czech Parliament meetings corpus, as well as the Danish Estonian Portuguese Slovenian in Hungarian corpora five other corpora.
Are available in Clarence Centers, but not through the vlog.

These are the Finnish, Greek, Swedish, British in the Europol corpus, where it is worth pointing out that the Europol corpus is available through the check repository Linda, but only a version that where the data are until 2003, which is an outdated version because I think the latest version of Europe all has dated until 2011.
Finally, as you can see, nine corpora aren't part of the client infrastructure, and I'll get back to this later.
What I'd like to point out is that finding this these corpora isn't easy, even in the case of those that are part of the infrastructure.
As I said, the first step that we took in the survey is was to try and find the corporate through the vlog, and this was already quite difficult.
For instance, if you type.
In a keyword like Parliament with the Wild card.
You you aren't able to find the Danish Portuguese and Slovenian corpora, even though it later turned out that they are indeed indexed by the vlo.
These were eventually identified.

Only after querying the full, the full names of these corpora and we believe that this is a quite a limitation, since many of the users who are interested in such resources won't know the official names.
Furthermore, it also turns out that using a keyword like the adjective Parliament, parliamentary returns even less desirable results.
There were about 130 resources with the same name.
Flemish Parliament parliamentary debate, debate, and it turned out that this isn't a corpus, but rather separate links in the vlog, two specific debates and the 1st.
Couple of pages were dominated by such resources and there were no corpora to be found.
Now the second batch of issues that we were able to identify pertains to the missing metadata.
As I mentioned at the beginning of my presentation, we also conducted similar overviews for other language resources like computer mediated communication, newspaper data, and parallel corpora.
And it must be said that in the case of the parliamentary corpora, their meta data are by far the best documented.
And there were missing metadata for only a handful of corpora.
The Latvian corpus, which isn't a part of the client infrastructure, lacks information regarding both its size and annotation.
The Estonian and Finnish corpora lack information regarding annotation.
However, the biggest problem with the metadata has to do with the license out of the 20 national corpora in the Europe, all core positive between identified there was.
If your licensing information only for three corpora, the Slovenian once slow Park Slope parallel, the Czech Parliament, Parliament, meetings corpus and the Finnish corpus.
Now.
As parliamentary corpora are of great value for researchers from a wide range of disciplines in a lot of effort has already been put in.
Producing them and maintaining them, we drafted a tentative list of suggestions for their developers or curators on the one hand.
Sorry.
I.
Think I got a bit lost.
Yeah.
We yeah.
So we we suggest that.
The metadata of some of the existing corpora into infrastructure be improved.
For instance, we suggest that.
Developers use terms like parliamentary in the title of the metadata file so that the corpus gets included in the target query.

We also suggest that developers provide descriptions in English and that these descriptions include terms like parliamentary and its variants which will then lead to higher ranking and this is one of the reasons why the Danish corpus couldn't be found even though with this part of the vlog its description is.
In is only in Danish and we also suggest and.
We also suggest that the developers provide licensing information which would help with the ranking.
Now finally.
We also suggest that.

The the corpora that aren't part of the client infrastructure be added to a national repository, and these are the Austrian, Bulgarian, Czech, German, Latvian, Lithuanian, Norwegian and Dutch corpora and.
Basically, to conclude, we.
As some of you might know, we also did.
As I mentioned.
We also did all reviews of the other resource families and they quite different in scope since for instance for CMC corpora.
We also found datasets and tools in parallel.
In the case of parallel corpora, we identified quite a lot of them, and in this case there were a lot of missing metadata and for newspaper corpora this is still work in progress so.
Any feedback here is welcome.
There are spread Google spreadsheets where we still collect the data for the newspaper corpora and.
Thank you.
